The fruit of such a planting is forbidden until the fifteenth of Shebaṭ.85‘The New Year for trees’, although the three years of ‘orlah are reckoned to have been completed by the previous New Year.

We go out to the cemetery and examine1To see if by chance there is life in them. This was the practice in ancient times when the dead were buried in caves and it was only necessary to lift the lid of the coffin to make an inspection. Cf. Ṭur Y.D., §394. the dead within three days and do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices.2lit. ‘the ways of the Amorites’. For examples of such practices, cf. Shab. 67a, b (Sonc. ed., pp. 320ff). It once happened that [a man who was buried] was examined [and found to be living], and he lived for twenty-five years and then died. Another3According to the reading of the Ṭur which omits ‘another’, this refers to the same man. [so examined lived and] begat five children before he died.

We erect a canopy4Not to deprive them of the ceremony of which they were deprived by death. for bridegrooms and brides [who died before marriage] and suspend from it articles which have and have not reached the edible stage; this is the opinion of R. Meir. R. Judah5GRA reads ‘the Sages’. said: We only suspend from it articles which have not reached the edible stage.6Because such fruit will become prohibited and therefore wasted, and to waste food is not permitted. These are what are suspended from it: Nuts which have not reached the edible stage,7GRA and H insert ‘pomegranates’ to make this list conform to the next sentence. loaves of bread which are not edible,8i.e. burnt or mouldy. strips of purple wool, flasks of perfumed oil. And these are the articles which may not be suspended from it: Nuts which have reached the edible stage, pomegranates which have reached the edible stage, loaves of bread which are edible, and flasks of sweet oil. The general rule is: no benefit may be derived from anything that is suspended from the canopy.

We scatter before bridegrooms and brides strings of fish9Fish strung on a line; cf. B.M. II, 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 130). and pieces of meat in summer but not in winter; but not pieces of cooked fish, mushrooms, truffles or sesame both in summer and winter; but one takes roasted ears of corn and nuts and throws them. The general rule is: we may not scatter before them anything that is perishable.

We may let wine and oil flow through pipes10Cf. Ber. 50b (Sonc. ed., p. 306). According to Büchler, this was done for the purpose of diffusing a sweet odour and do honour to distinguished guests (M.G.W.J., XLIX, pp. 12ff). before bridegrooms and brides and we do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices; nor do we fear of sinning by putting food to shame.11i.e. wasting it. So GRA, V has ‘their prohibition’. It is related that Judah and Hillel, the sons of Rabban Gamaliel, came to Ben Zakkai at Kabul12A town S.E. of Akko in northern Palestine. and the citizens let wine and oil flow through pipes [in their honour].

We may burn [articles]13So that others may not use them; cf. ‘A.Z. 11a (Sonc. ed., p. 57). at the funerals of kings and mutilate [their animals], and we do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices. Any mutilation which disqualifies the animal as food makes it forbidden to be eaten, but benefit may be derived from it; and when the mutilation does not disqualify the animal it may be eaten and obviously benefit may be derived from it. Which mutilation disqualifies it? From the knee downwards.14Corrected in agreement with Ḥul. 76a (Sonc. ed., p. 419). V and H read ‘upwards’.

We may burn articles at the funeral of kings but not at the funeral of princes.15Cf. ‘A.Z. loc. cit. GRA reads: ‘As we burn articles at the funeral of kings, so do we likewise at the funeral of princes’. When Rabban Gamaliel the Elder died, the proselyte Onḳelos burnt after him more than eighty Tyrian minas. They asked him, ‘What was your purpose in doing this?’ He replied, ‘It is written, Thou16Addressed to Zedekiah, king of Judah. shalt die in peace; and with the burnings of thy fathers, the former kings that were before thee, so shall they make a burning for thee.17Jer. 34, 5. And is not Rabban Gamaliel worth more than a hundred useless kings?’

We cover the hair of [dead] brides, uncover the face of [dead] bridegrooms,18As a sign of grief. and place ink and pen at their side,19As if to say that had the bridegroom lived he would have written a kethubah for his bride. and we do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices.
20GRA deletes this paragraph which is printed by V in brackets. It has no relevance to the context and is derived from Sanh. 11a (Sonc. ed., p. 44). The text is in great disorder.(When Rabban Gamaliel the Elder entered [the meeting place of the Rabbis to intercalate the year], he found eight [present]. He asked, ‘Who is it that entered without permission?’ Samuel the Small arose and said, ‘Rabbi, I entered only to inquire about the law [of intercalation]’.21And not to take part in the proceedings without invitation. He answered, ‘O Eldad and Medad,22Cf. Num. 11, 26. They were worthy that the Spirit of God should alight upon them. all Israel know that if I had ordered that only two should enter, you would have been one [of them] to enter’.)23So highly was Samuel the Small esteemed.
We suspend the key and writing-tablet of a dead man from his coffin from grief of soul. When Samuel the Small died, they suspended his key and writing-tablet from his coffin because he had no son, and when Rabban Gamaliel the Elder and R. Eleazar delivered their funeral orations over him, they exclaimed, ‘For this one it is fitting to weep, for this one it is fitting to mourn. When kings die they leave their crowns to their sons; when wealthy men die they leave their riches to their children; but Samuel the Small has taken away with him all the desirable things in the world and has departed’. And thus he24i.e. Samuel the Small under the influence of the Holy Spirit. spoke at the time of his death, ‘Simeon [b. Gamaliel] and Ishmael [the son of Elisha the High Priest]25They met their death after the capture of Jerusalem. are destined for the sword and the rest of the people for spoliation; great distress will befall [Israel] after them’. He uttered these words in Aramaic.

26[Cf. ARN XXXVIII, 3, above pp. 191ff.] When R. Simeon b. Gamaliel and R. Ishmael came [to be tried], it was decreed against them that they should be put to death. Whereupon R. Ishmael broke into tears; and R. Simeon said to him, ‘Abrek,27A title of honour (cf. Gen. 41, 43). It was interpreted by the Rabbis as the initial letters of the Heb. phrase, ‘father in wisdom though tender in years’; cf. Midrash Rabbah, Genesis, XC, 3 (Sonc. ed., p. 829). why do you weep? Two steps more28i.e. immediately. and you will be in the bosom of the righteous, and yet you weep!’ He replied, ‘Do I then weep because we are about to be executed? It is because we are about to be executed [in the same way] as murderers and desecrators of the Sabbath’. He said to him, ‘Perhaps you were having a meal or you were sleeping when a woman came to ask [a ruling] concerning her ritual impurity or her cleanness, and your servant told her that you were asleep. And the Torah states, Ye shall not aflict29Keeping an anxious woman waiting is a form of affliction. any widow or fatherless child. If thou afflict them in any wise—for if they cry at all unto Me, I will surely hear their cry.30Ex. 22, 21f. And what is written after this? My wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you with the sword’. Some say that it was [47b] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel who was weeping and R. Ishmael who answered him in these words.
When R. Simeon and R. Ishmael were executed and the report reached R. ‘Aḳiba and R. Judah b. Baba, they arose, girded their loins with sackcloth, rent their garments and exclaimed, ‘Our brother-Israelites, if good were destined to come to the world, at first none would receive it but R. Simeon and R. Ishmael; but now that it is revealed before Him Who spake and the universe came into being that eventually great punishments will come upon the world, they have consequently been taken out of the world; [as it is stated,] The righteous perisheth, and no man layeth it to heart,31Isa. 57, 1. and it continues, He entereth into peace, they rest in their beds’.32ibid. 2.

When R. ‘Aḳiba was executed in Caesarea and the news reached R. Judah b. Baba and R. Ḥanina b. Teradion, they arose, girded themselves in sackcloth, rent their garments and exclaimed, ‘Our brethren, hearken unto us! R. ‘Aḳiba was not executed for robbery or because he did not labour in the Torah with all his strength. He has only been put to death as a sign,33Of great misfortunes to come. as it is stated, Thus shall Ezekiel be unto you a sign; according to all that he hath done shall ye do; when this cometh, then shall ye know that I am the Lord God.34Ezek. 24, 24; verses 15-27 describe the symbols of Ezekiel’s bereavement. Within a short while there will be no place found in the land of Israel where no [slain] will be cast forth, as it is stated, Speak: Thus saith the Lord—And the carcasses of men fall as dung upon the open field, and as the handful after the harvestman, which none gathereth’.35Jer. 9, 21. It is reported that it was not long before war came and disturbed the world, and within twelve months the municipalities36Heb. bula’oth, the Greek for ‘senate, city-council’. Büchler, The Economic Conditions of Judaea, p. 28, n. 2, defines the term as ‘open places as opposed to fortified towns’. in Judea ceased; as it is stated, Tremble, ye women that are at ease; be troubled, ye confident ones:37Isa. 32, 11. Ye women that are at ease refers to the municipalities in Judea, ye confident ones refers to the fortified towns.38Cf. Büchler, loc. cit. Confident ones is nothing else than a term for walled cities.39Heb. ṭeraksin which Jastrow takes to be a corruption of kerakim, ‘walled cities’. [The sentence is apparently a marginal note, and it is difficult to see how a common word should have been misread as an unusual one. Krauss, Lehnwörter, pp. 274f more probably ‘enclosures’.] It is reported that twelve months had not passed before what had been said was fulfilled.

R. Meir illustrated it by a parable. To what is the matter like? To a king who prepared a banquet and invited guests without fixing a time when they should leave. The shrewd among them left at the ninth hour,40i.e. 3 p.m. returned home and went to bed while it was still light; others left at sunset while the shops were still open and the lamps burning, entered their homes and went to bed by the light of the lamps; still others left at two or three hours in the night when some shops were open and some shut, some with their lamps alight and some with their lamps extinguished, entered their homes and went to bed in the dark. Those remaining at the banquet became intoxicated, and wounded and killed each other; as it is stated, I saw the Lord standing beside the altar; and He said: Smite the capitals, that the posts may shake; and break them in pieces on the head of all of them; and I will slay the residue of them with the sword.41Amos 9, 1.

When R. Ḥanina b. Teradion was arrested42So GRA and H; V has ‘entered’. on the charge of heresy,43His heresy consisted in occupying himself with the Torah when it was forbidden by the Romans. Cf. ‘A.Z. 17b (Sonc. ed., p. 90), Sifrë, §307. [the Romans] sentenced him to be burnt, his wife to be executed and his daughter to be consigned to a brothel. He asked, ‘What have they decreed against that poor woman?’ They replied, ‘She is to be executed’. Thereupon he recited of her the verse, The Lord is righteous in all his ways.44Ps. 145, 17. She asked, ‘What have they decreed against the Rabbi?’ They replied, ‘He is to be burnt’. Thereupon she recited of him the verse, Great in counsel, and mighty in work.45Jer. 32, 19.
When they burnt him, they wrapped him in a scroll of the Torah and burnt him. His daughter wept, wailed and threw herself before him. Whereupon he exclaimed, ‘My daughter, if for me you weep, if for me you throw yourself down, it were better that a fire which [a man] has fanned should consume me and not one which [a man] has not fanned;46i.e. the fires of Gehinnom. as it is stated, A fire not blown by man shall consume him.47Job 20, 26. If, however, you threw yourself down because of the scroll of the Torah, behold, the letters are flying upwards and only parchment is being consumed. For even great servants of the king are punished by inferior servants, [as it is stated,] Therefore have I hewed them by the prophets, I have slain them by the words of My mouth’.48Hos. 6, 5. The prophets, the servants of God, endeavoured to hew Israel into shape but the people ill-treated them.

49H transposes the two paragraphs. [On this passage, cf. Büchler, Sin and Atonement, pp. 165ff and his comment upon the use of the verb ba‘aṭ, lit. ‘kick’ in the sense of ‘protest’.] R. ‘Aḳiba said: A king had four sons. One was silent when punished, another protested when punished, another begged for mercy when punished, and another when punished said to his father, ‘Go on punishing me’. Abraham remained silent when punished, as it is stated, Take now thy son, thine only son, whom thou lovest, even Isaac … and offer him there for a burnt-offering.50Gen. 22, 2. He could have argued, ‘Yesterday You said to me, For in Isaac shall seed be called to thee!’51ibid. XXI, 12. Then it is stated, And Abraham rose early in the morning.52ibid. XXII, 3. He submitted to God’s decree in silence. Job protested when punished, as it is stated, I will say unto God: Do not condemn me; make me know wherefore Thou contendest with me.53Job 10, 2. Hezekiah besought God for mercy when punished, as it is stated, Then he turned his face to the wall, and prayed unto the Lord, saying,542 Kings 20, 2. etc. Some say that Hezekiah protested when he was punished since he later added, And have done that which is good in Thy sight.55ibid. 3. The verse, in which he claimed innocence, is understood as a protest against his fate. David [when punished] said to his Father, ‘Continue to punish me’, as it is stated, Wash me thoroughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.56Ps. 51, 4. David interpreted his suffering as purification of his sin and asked God to do it thoroughly.

We do not interrupt the study of the Torah until the soul departs from the dying man.57What follows is also related in M.Ḳ. 21b (Sonc. ed., pp. 135f). [For the variations in the two versions, cf. Bacher, Ag. d. Tannaiten, pp. 298f.] When R. Simeon, the son of R. ‘Aḳiba, fell ill, the latter did not interrupt his expositions in the Academy but made inquiries after him through a messenger. The first messenger came and reported, ‘He is very ill’. He said to [his disciples], ‘Continue to ask questions’. Then a second came and reported, ‘He has grown worse’. R. ‘Aḳiba resumed the study of the Torah. A third came and reported, ‘He is dying’, and he said [to his disciples, ‘Continue] to ask questions’. A fourth came and reported, ‘He is dead’.58lit. ‘he has completed [his life]’. Whereupon he arose, removed the tefillin,59Pious men wore them throughout the day. rent his garments and said to them, ‘Our brother-Israelites, hearken! Until now we had the duty to study the Torah; but from now onward we have the duty to occupy ourselves with honouring the dead’.
A large assembly gathered to bury R. ‘Aḳiba’s son, and he said to them, ‘Bring a bench60To improvise a rostrum. for me to the cemetery’. He stood61GRA reads ‘stood’. upon it and expounded, ‘Our brother-Israelites, hearken! Not because I am a scholar [have you come here], there being greater scholars here than I; not because I am a rich man [have you come here], there being richer men here than I; the men of the Darom62Southern Palestine. know R. ‘Aḳiba, but how should the men of Galilee know him?63A gibe at the Galileans who were not careful to reproduce the traditions which they received from their teachers and their inability to retain their learning. On Judeans and Galileans, cf. ‘Erub. 53a (Sonc. ed., pp. 370f). Men know him, but how should women and young children? I know, however, that your reward is great because you have only taken the great trouble to come here for the honour of the Torah and for the sake of the commandment [to attend the dead to the grave]. I should be comforted though I had seven sons whom I [now] buried. Not that a man desires to bury his children, but I know that my son is destined for the World to Come because he caused the many to be righteous, and64From here to the end of the paragraph is quoted from Aboth V, 21 (Sonc. ed., V, 18, p. 71). whoever causes the many to be righteous, sin occurs not through him, and whoever causes the many to sin, they do not afford him the faculty to repent. Moses was righteous and caused the many to be righteous, [therefore] the righteousness of the many was [considered] dependent on him, as it is stated, He executed the righteousness of the Lord, and His ordinances with Israel.65Deut. 33, 21. Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, sinned and caused others to sin, [therefore] the sin of the many was [considered] dependent on him, as it is stated, For the sins of Jeroboam which he sinned, and wherewith he made Israel to sin’.661 Kings 15, 30.

Further [R. ‘Aḳiba] sat on the bench [and taught]: Good things are brought about through the agency of good men.67Cf. Shab. 32a (Sonc. ed., p. 146). Even if Moses and Aaron had not arisen, Israel would still have been worthy to be redeemed from Egypt,68Because of the promise God made to Abraham. as it is stated, And afterward shall they come out with great substance.69Gen. 15, 14. Had not Moses and Aaron and the Generation of the Wilderness arisen, Israel would still have been worthy to receive the Torah, as it is stated, He layeth up sound wisdom for the upright.70Prov. 2, 7, sound wisdom being a synonym for the Torah and the upright for Israel. The section of ‘the judges’71Ex. 18, 21-23. would have been worthy to be promulgated even if Jethro had not arisen. The section of ‘the smaller Passover’72Num. 9, 1-14, also known as the ‘second Passover’. would have been worthy to be promulgated even if the ‘unclean’ had not arisen, as it is stated, We are unclean by the dead body of a man; wherefore are we to be kept back, so as not to bring the offering of the Lord in its appointed season among the children of Israel?73ibid. 7. The section of ‘inheritance’74ibid.XXVII, 6-11. would have been worthy to be promulgated even if the daughters of Zelophehad75ibid. 1-5. had not arisen. The Temple would have been worthy to be built even if David and Solomon had not arisen, as it is stated, The sanctuary, O Lord, which Thy hands have established.76Ex. 15, 17. Israel would have been worthy to be redeemed in the days of Haman even it Mordecai and Esther had not arisen, as it is stated, And yet for all that, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them, neither will I abhor them, to destroy them utterly,77Lev. 26, 44. etc.
Israel were destined to be enslaved even if Pharaoh had not arisen in Egypt, as it is stated, And [they] shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years.78Gen. 15, 13. Israel were destined to serve idols even if Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, had not arisen, as it is stated, And this people will rise up, and go astray after the foreign gods of the land.79Deut. 31, 16. The section of ‘the blasphemer’80Lev. 24, 10ff. and of ‘the gatherer of sticks’81Num. 15 32-36. would have been worthy to be promulgated even if the son of the Israelitish woman and the gatherer of sticks had not arisen. Israel would have been destined to be destroyed by the sword even if so and so82i.e. nations hostile to Israel. They were so many that they are not specified. had not arisen, as it is stated, All the sinners of My people shall die by the sword;83Amos.Cf. IX, 10. and it declares, By sword and famine shall they be consumed.84Jer. 14, 15. Israel would have deserved to be destroyed even if Nebuchadnezzar and his companions had not arisen, as it is stated, Therefore shall Zion for your sake be ploughed as a field, and Jerusalem shall become heaps, and the mountain of the house as the high places of a forest.85Micah 3, 12.

And further [he expounded]: Reward is brought about through persons of merit and punishment through persons of guilt. 86E.V. those prophets be consumed. Cf. IX, 10. Ta‘an. 18b (Sonc. ed., p. 89).When Trajan was about to execute Pappus and his brother Lulianus in Laodicea, he said to them, ‘If you are of the people of Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, let your God come and deliver you from my hands, in the same way as He delivered Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah [from Nebuchadnezzar]’. They replied, ‘Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah were worthy men and Nebuchadnezzar was a worthy king, and it was fitting that a miracle should be wrought through their agency; but you are a wicked king and are not worthy that a miracle should be wrought through your agency. As for us, we deserve death at the hand of God, and if you do not slay us, the Omnipresent has many other agents of death; He has many demons, many bears, many leopards, many snakes, many venomous serpents, many scorpions which will come and attack us; but when we die you will learn that we are the descendants of Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah’. It is reported that before they died they witnessed his eyes gouged out.87The parallel passage in Ta‘an. reads, ‘two officials arrived from Rome and split his skull with clubs’.

The allegorical interpreters88lit. ‘expounders of jewels’, i.e. precious ethical principles. These interpreters stressed the idea behind the law and not its fulfilment. This type of interpretation was a product of Alexandria and was strongly opposed by the Talmudical Rabbis. Cf. Lauterbach, Jewish Quarterly Review (new series), I, pp. 503ff. of Scripture said: And ye shall break down their altars:89Deut. 12, 3. wherein have the trees and the stones sinned?90Cf. Sanh. 55a (Sonc. ed., p. 374). Because they were a stumbling-block to man Scripture decreed, And ye shall break down. This is an argument from minor to major: if with trees and stones, which are capable neither of merit nor guilt, neither of good nor evil, because they were a stumbling-block to man the Torah declared, And ye shall break down, how much more [will a man be punished] who causes his neighbour to sin and turns him away from the way of life to the path of death! Similarly, And if a woman approach unto any beast, and lie down thereto, thou shalt kill the woman, and the beast.91Lev. 20, 16. If a human being sinned, how has the animal offended?92Sanh. 54a (Sonc. ed., p. 367). Because evil came to a human being through it, and so that the animal shall not pass through the street and people say, ‘This is the animal on account of which So-and-so was stoned’. This is an argument from minor to major: if with an animal, which is capable neither of merit nor guilt, neither of good nor evil, because it was a stumbling-block to a human being the Torah declared, It shall be stoned, how much more [will a man be punished] who causes his neighbour to sin and turns him from the way of life to the path of death!
Similarly Scripture declares of the stones of the altar, Thou shalt lift up no iron tool upon them,93Deut. 27, 5. and elsewhere it states, For if thou lift up thy tool upon it, thou hast profaned it.94Ex. 20, 22. Wherein is iron different from all other metals to be unfit for [the building of] the altar? Because the sword is a symbol of curse and the altar an agent of atonement; so we remove the symbol of curse on account of the agent of atonement. This is an argument from minor to major: if with the stones of the altar which do not see and speak, eat or drink, because they make peace between Israel and their Father in heaven the Torah declared, Thou shalt lift no iron tool upon them, the children of the Torah,95The people of Israel. who are an atonement for the world, how much more [should they not lift an iron tool against each other!] Similarly Scripture declares, Thou shalt build the altar of the Lord thy God of unhewn stones96Deut. 27, 6.—stones that bring peace to the world. This is an argument from minor to major: if with stones which do not see or hear, speak or eat or drink, because they make peace between Israel and their Father in heaven they must be ‘whole’ [48a] before [the Holy One, blessed be He], how much more the children of the Torah, who are an atonement for the world, must be ‘whole’ before the Holy One, blessed be He!

One does not rend [his garments] for the dead1If they are not his near of kin. except for his teacher who taught him wisdom.2i.e. Torah. Cf., however, M.Ḳ. 25a (Sonc. ed., p. 154), Shab. 105b (Sonc. ed., p. 509) where it is taught that one rends the garments on the death of any worthy man. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: When a Sage dies, all present at his death rend [their garments] for him, but all those who are not present do not rend them.

For a Sage who died3M.Ḳ. 22b (Sonc. ed., pp. 143f). one bares the right [shoulder]; for an ’Ab Beth Din who died one bares the left [shoulder]; for a Nasi’ who died one bares both shoulders.4lit. ‘hands’. It is related5Sanh. 68a (Sonc. ed., pp. 463f). that when R. Eliezer died, R. ‘Aḳiba bared both shoulders and kept on beating his heart6For ‘heart’ Sanh. reads ‘his flesh’. until the blood flowed, and he cried out, ‘My father, my father, the chariots of Israel and the horsemen thereof!’72 Kings 2, 12.

8M.Ḳ. 22b (Sonc. ed., p. 140). One does not bare [the shoulder] for the dead in general but only for his father and mother; and if they are not worthy,9e.g. if the son is a distinguished scholar, as it would be undignified for him to be seen with bared shoulders; cf. Ṭur Y.D., §340. he does not rend even for his father and mother. It is related that when R. ‘Aḳiba’s father died, those present bared [the shoulder], but he did not.
For the dead in general one rends [the garments] with a knife,10M.Ḳ. 22b (Sonc. ed., p. 143). but for his father and mother he does not rend with a knife.11But with the hand.
For the dead in general one does not bare his chest, but for his father and mother he bares it.12M.Ḳ. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 142). ‘Chest’ is lit. ‘heart’.

For the dead in general one does not divide13ibid. the [upper] selvage-border [of his garment],14i.e. about the neck and shoulders. but for his father and mother he does divide it. R. Judah said: Any rending [of a garment] which does not divide the selvage-border is mere make-believe. R. Judah said:15M.Ḳ. 26b (Sonc. ed., p. 169). Any initial rending must be [to the extent of] three fingers, while the extension may be as small as he cares.16lit. ‘whatever it be’, i.e. when the tear is extended for another death. One only rends as far down as the region of the navel.17If a succession of deaths occurs, that is the limit to which the tear may extend. In the case of children, others rend for them.18The reading in M.Ḳ. is ‘children are made to rend’; not that they are under the obligation to do so, but in order to arouse sadness in those who witness it. One who rends [not as a relative but] from respect [for the dead] may stitch [the edges] forthwith. The rending of one’s undershirt is not indispensable.19Cf. M.Ḳ. 22b (Sonc. ed., p. 142). R. Benjamin said in the name of R. ‘Aḳiba: One must rend the undershirt.

20ibid. For the dead in general one rends only the uppermost [garment], but for his father and mother he must rend [all] even though he be wearing a hundred. A woman only rends her uppermost [garment]. R. Judah said: A woman rends her undergarment, turns it front to back, and then rends the remaining [garments].21So as not to expose her chest.

For the dead generally one tacks22With large basting stitches. the rent together after seven days, and [completely] restitches [the edges] after thirty; but for one’s father and mother one never restitches [the edges]. A woman tacks the rent together after seven [days] and restitches [the edges] after thirty. R. Judah said: A woman tacks the rent together immediately23From a sense of self-respect (M.Ḳ. loc. cit.). and restitches [the edges] after seven [days].24So GRA and H; V reads ‘three’.

25Cf. M.Ḳ. 22a (Sonc. ed., p. 140). For the dead generally one expedites26i.e. hastens the interment. the bier and does not occupy himself unduly with their affairs;27viz. their business affairs before the funeral (Rashi). R. Ḥananel, on the basis of a passage in j.M.Ḳ. III, 8, 83d, explains ‘reduces the funeral expenses and the lament to a minimum’. but in the case of his father and mother, whoever greatly occupies himself with their affairs and does not expedite the bier is praiseworthy. But if time is pressing, or the Sabbath-eve is approaching, or rain falls, he may expedite the bier for his father and mother and does not unduly occupy himself with their affairs.

For the dead in general it is forbidden to wear pressed clothes until thirty days [are completed], but in the case of his father and mother it is forbidden until the [next] Festival occurs and then only if his companions rebuke him.28On his untidy appearance.

29M.Ḳ. 22b (Sonc. ed., p. 141). For the dead generally it is forbidden to trim one’s hair until thirty days are completed; but in the case of his father and mother, one lets the hair grow long until his companions rebuke him.

For the dead generally one is forbidden to engage in trade30Not ordinary trade which is permissible after seven days of mourning, but to set out on a business journey to distant lands, because that might be interpreted as an indication of callousness. until thirty days are completed; but for one’s father and mother until his companions rebuke him and say to him, ‘Come out with us’.

31Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit. For the dead generally it is forbidden to go to a house of feasting until thirty days are completed; but for one’s father and mother, all the twelve months unless it is for a sacred cause.32e.g. a wedding.

If news reached him that his father died and he rent, but [in fact] it was his mother, he has done his duty.33He has not to rend again. [If news reached him that] his mother died, but it was his father and he rent, he has done his duty. [If news reached him that] his father died and he rent, but it was one of his near relatives, he has done his duty. [If news reached him that] one of his near relatives died, but it was his father, he has not done his duty.34He has to rend again.

If one’s father and mother died [at the same time], he makes only one rent for the two of them.35Cf. M.Ḳ. 26b (Sonc. ed., p. 170). R. Judah b. Tema said: He rends for each separately. If one’s ten children died at the same time, he makes one rent for all of them.
36ibid.If after he had made a rent [for another] news reached him that his son died, he continues to rend until it [reaches down] to the navel; when it has reached the navel he turns [the garment] front to back.
If his son died and he rent [and news of another death reached him], he leaves a space of three fingers and again rends.

37The text is corrupt, and the translation follows the version of Nachmanides (cf. N.Y.). The rent must be made only between the two borders;38On either side of the front opening of the shirt or tunic. one who makes the rent along the border or at the side has not done his duty.39Because the rent is hidden. R. Judah said: He has done his duty. R. Judah said: It happened in the days of Ḥarsum40The name of a High Priest who lived in a time of persecution. GRA reads ḥerum which means ‘prohibition to travel’, e.g. in a time of war. that people used to make the rent at the lower end [of the garment] and at the side. His colleagues retorted, ‘No proof may be adduced [from a practice adopted] in a time of danger’.
A man dressed in torn garments does not rend.41Since his garments are already torn, the new rent will not be distinguishable. R. Judah said: One who rends a cloak of Birrus,42‘A cloth named after a Celtic people, Burri’ (Krauss); ‘a cloak of thick woollen material’ (Jastrow). a Brundisian cloak,43A cloak thicker than the previous material (Jastrow); a cloth named after a Celtic people, the Burridens (Krauss). a Poenula,44A travelling cloak (Jastrow). a stitched garment or a veil,45Jastrow emends חרוד to רדיד, a garment of fine texture. has not done his duty.46These materials are either too thick or too fine for the rent to be distinguishable. One who rends a basted garment47i.e. one sewn with large stitches. has done his duty. What constitutes a basted garment? [When its tear] has been completely basted.

These are the rents which may not be basted: [When it was done] for his father or mother, for his teacher who instructed him in wisdom, for a scroll of the Torah which has been burnt, for the ruined Temple, for evil tidings, [on hearing] the Divine Name blasphemed, on seeing Jerusalem from Mount Scopus,48Because from there the ruins of Jerusalem are visible. and [on the death of] a Nasi’. Some add: [On the death of] a High Priest, a prophet, or an ’Ab Beth Din. As regards the burning of a scroll of the Torah, [the garment is rent] not on hearing of this happening but only when he stands by while it burns. As for the ruined Temple, [he rends his garment] even if he heard that it has been destroyed; similarly with evil tidings because they are as grievous as the destruction of the Temple.
One who sees Jerusalem from Mount Scopus must rend; when he enters [the city] he extends the rent, and if he goes up [again to Jerusalem] he must extend it further. ‘If he goes up again’—this is to teach that he is obliged to make a rent every time he goes up [to Jerusalem] during each period [of thirty days].49[The meaning is illustrated by j.Ber. IX, 2, 13d: R. Simeon Ḳamṭraya asked R. Ḥiyya b. Abba, ‘Since I am an ass-driver and go up to Jerusalem throughout the year, how is it about rending my garment?’ He replied, ‘Within thirty days [after a visit] it is unnecessary for you to rend’.] If he came up [to Jerusalem] and settled there, he rends once and has thereby done his duty.

One who buys a tunic which has been rent [by a mourner] from50So GRA and H; V has ‘for’. his companion may not baste it unless he knows that the rent is of the kind which may be basted. One who sells a tunic which has been rent [by a mourner] to his companion must inform him whether the rent is of the kind which may be basted or not.51Cf. M.Ḳ. 26b (Sonc. ed., p. 169). All rent [garments] which may not be basted must not be sold to non-Jews52Lest they resell it to a Jew. or stitched together or be reversed from top to bottom, according to the view of R. Simeon; but R. Eliezer permits it to be done. 53Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 172).One who borrows a tunic from his companion to go and visit his father and when he arrives finds that his father died, he rends it, bastes it and returns it to his companion. If, however, he borrowed it without specifying for what purpose he needed it, he is not permitted54This is the reading of GRA and H. to rend it.

55Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit. One who goes out before the bier of the dead with a garment already rent robs the dead [of his due]. More grievous is the robbing of the dead than robbing the living, because one who robs the living can appease him by making restitution, but one who robs the dead cannot appease him by making restitution.
56This sentence and the next Rule are transposed in accordance with GRA. A better sequence is thereby obtained.Likewise you may say: One who honours his father and mother after their death57Cf. Ḳid. 31b (Sonc. ed., p. 154). is as if he honoured them in their lifetime, since one who honours them while they are alive may do so from fear or for the sake of an inheritance; but he who honours them after their death does so in the name of Heaven only.58To fulfil God’s command and without a motive of self-interest.
He who made a rent for one [presumed] dead and he revived, if he dies immediately afterwards [the man who made a rent] has fulfilled his duty, but if [death occurred] after some time he has not done his duty.59Cf. Ned. 87a (Sonc. ed., p. 268).

Whosoever rescues garments from the dead60Cf. Sanh. 48a, b (Sonc. ed., pp. 321f). If parents piled on the bier garments belonging to their child as an expression of grief and as a sign that they renounced everything that belonged to him. Saving the garments constituted an act of returning lost property; but when the articles touched the bier they were regarded as designated for the dead. robs the dead. There are times when a man may rescue them and times when he may not. [48b] If the garments have not touched the bier he may rescue them, but if they have touched the bier he may not. We, however, instruct people not to seize them.61V inserts ‘but did not [the Sages] say’ which GRA deletes. And whoever piles up garments on the dead commits a transgression because of the law which forbids wilful destruction,62The Rabbis derived a law against the wanton destruction of articles from Deut. 20, 19; cf. Shab. 129a (Sonc. ed., p. 644, n. 1). according to the view of R. Meir. R. Eliezer b. Ẓadoḳ said: It disgraces him. Rabban Gamaliel said: He causes maggots to breed upon [the dead]. R. Nathan said: The garment which goes down with him to the grave will come back with him in the time to come,63In the Resurrection; cf. j.Keth. XII, 3, 35a, Sanh. 90b (Sonc. ed., p. 607). as it is stated, It is changed as clay under the seal; and they stand as a garment.64Job 38, 14; לְבו·שׁ, a garment, is homiletically read as לָבו·שׁ, ‘as he is dressed’.

A mourner, as long as his dead is lying before him,1i.e. before the burial for which he has to make arrangements; cf. Ber. 18a (Sonc. ed., p. 106). is exempt from reading the Shema‘ and Tefillah and from all the commandments prescribed in the Torah. Even if he desires to place himself under greater restrictions [than the law requires] he should not do so out of respect for the dead.

2Cf. Ber. 19a (Sonc. ed., p. 116). When the time comes for reading the Shema‘, all the people [present] read it but he remains silent; when they stand to read the Tefillah, all read it but he justifies for himself the divine decree. What does he say? ‘Sovereign of all the universe, I have sinned before Thee; I have repaid but few of my obligations; I merit much more punishment than this; may it be Thy will to repair our breaches and to comfort us’. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: He also prays for all the needs of the dead person.

3ibid. 17b-18a (Sonc. ed., p. 102), M.Ḳ. 23b (Sonc. ed., p. 146). A mourner eats [his meal] in the house of his neighbour, and if he has no neighbour he eats it in another room; and if he has no other room [than that in which the dead is lying], he puts up a partition and eats; and if he is not able to put up a partition, he turns his face away from the dead and eats. But he must not eat in a reclining posture,4At meals people usually reclined on the left elbow on a couch as a mark of ease. eat as much food as he needs, eat meat or drink wine. He is not included in the Zimmun, others do not say Grace on his behalf, and we do not request him, ‘Say Grace’.5This means to lead the company in Grace after meals; but the Gemara, Ber. 17b (Sonc. ed., p. 107), reads ‘and he does not say a blessing [over food]’, which Rashi interprets as referring to Grace before meals. When does this apply? On week-days, but on the Sabbath6When there is no outward mourning. he eats as much as he needs, he may eat meat and drink wine, and is included in the Zimmun. Rabban Gamaliel said: A mourner [is regarded] on the Sabbath as if he were not a mourner.
We do not remove the body [for burial] near [the time of] reading the Shema‘, unless it is an hour before.7V and H add ‘or they postpone it for an hour’ which GRA deletes.

8Cf. Ber. 17b (Sonc. ed., p. 106). Once the bearers of the bier have carried [the body] out—such as are before the bier9Awaiting their turn to relieve the bearers. and such as are behind it10These have already carried the coffin and so have done their duty.—those who are before the bier, whose services are still needed, are exempt from reading the Shema‘ and are forbidden11V has ‘permitted’; but GRA emends: ‘are forbidden to wear shoes; but as for those who are behind the bier whose services are no longer required, they are obliged to read the Shema‘ and, permitted to wear shoes’. to wear shoes. All alike are exempt from the Tefillah and from putting on the tefillin.

12Ber. loc. cit. Having buried the dead and returned [from the graveside], if they are able to begin and complete [the reading of the Shema‘] before arriving at the row,13To offer condolence to the mourners. they read14The text is corrupt, and the translation follows the reading of GRA and H. it and afterwards stand in the row; but if not, they stand in the row and afterwards read [the Shema‘] and the Tefillah.

15Cf. Ber. 19b (Sonc. ed., p. 117). The inner row [of the comforters] who can see the mourners is exempt [from reading the Shema‘], but the outer row is under the obligation. R. Judah said: Even if there be [only] one row, those who stand for the sake of [comforting] the mourner are exempt, but those who stand for the sake of [their own] honour16Ber. loc. cit. reads ‘for their own purposes’, i.e. to see the crowd. [are under the obligation].17The words in brackets are added by H. If they came to the memorial address,18So H; GRA reads ‘to comfort’. The word in V is corrupt. those who can see the mourners are exempt and those who cannot see them are under the obligation.

R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: Rabban Gamaliel had a borrowed grave19It is not mentioned elsewhere in Rabbinic literature and what it denotes is uncertain. It probably means a sepulchre owned by Rabban Gamaliel which was lent for the purpose described when it was required. in Jabneh where they brought the dead and locked the door behind it. Men came, stood in the row and comforted the mourners and the public was thereby exempt [from this duty]. Later [the bodies] were conveyed to Jerusalem [for burial].

After [the tomb] was closed with the top stone, [the mourner] muffles his head.20As a sign of mourning; cf. M.Ḳ. 15a (Sonc. ed., p. 88). Should he take his stand in the row,21When present at another funeral before returning home. he unmuffles his head and exempts others [from standing in the row for him]. When he leaves the row he muffles his head. After he has entered his house, should others come to comfort him, he unmuffles his head and exempts them.

22This is Rule 11 in H. When a Sage or a disciple suffers bereavement, people come and sit down before him and discuss the laws relating to mourners. Should they make a mistake he corrects them in a low tone, but he does not ask questions.23On the laws of mourning, because that would be studying Torah which is forbidden to a mourner. If he so desire he may speak personally to them, and if not he appoints someone to be his spokesman. It is related that when his son died, R. Judah appointed someone to be his spokesman. It is related that when his son died, R. Jose the Galilean appointed someone to be his spokesman. It is related that when his son died, R. ‘Aḳiba continued his discourse all the day.24Cf. above VIII, 13ff. The same is also reported of Rabbi [Judah the Prince]; he continued his discourse all the day.

25Cf. M.Ḳ. 23a (Sonc. ed., p. 144). This is Rule 12 in H. In the first week a mourner does not enter the Synagogue; in the second week he enters but does not sit in his [usual] place; in the third week he enters and sits in his [usual] place but does not speak; in the fourth week he is like any other person. R. Simeon said: In the first week26V adds in brackets ‘and the second week’. people come up to him to comfort him; the second week is treated like the first, the third like the second, and in the fourth week he is like any other person. R. Meir said: In the first and second week he does not enter the Synagogue, in the third he enters and sits in his [usual] place, and in the fourth he is like any other person. To what does this apply? To a Synagogue, but as for a House of Study he may enter it even in the first week.

27This paragraph is Rule 10 in H in a fuller form.On the Sabbath-eve at dusk he unmuffles his head; at the termination of the Sabbath he muffles it again. On the Sabbath-eve at dusk he turns back [the garment which is] rent; at the termination of the Sabbath he turns it to the front.

28This is Rule 13 in H. The text here is in disorder and the translation follows the emendation of GRA; cf. M.Ḳ. 22b (Sonc. ed., p. 144). When a Sage dies, his Beth Hammidrash goes into vacation and all the others change their place. When an ’Ab Beth Din dies, all the other Houses of Study in his city go into vacation and the others change their place. When a Nasi’ dies, all the Houses of Study go into vacation; people do not walk about in the street but enter [their homes] and sit in silence overcome by distress like men without a leader. When the time of rising arrives, they stand up and reduce their affairs to a minimum. The people of the Synagogue enter the Synagogue [on the Sabbath] and seven persons read the weekly portion of the Torah and go away.

29Cf. M.Ḳ. 23a (Sonc. ed., p. 144). This is Rule 14 in H. Neither Halakah nor ’Aggada should be expounded in the Beth Hammidrash of a mourner. Should a question be raised, they begin with the laws relating to mourners, pass on to other themes and revert to and end with the laws relating to mourners.
30This is Rule 15 in H in a different form.R. Ḥanina b. Gamaliel said: We may discourse upon an aggadic theme in the Beth Hammidrash of a mourner. In Judea they greeted mourners [on the Sabbath] on their entry and departure to indicate that there is no mourning on the Sabbath.

In a city where there are two dead, they take out the first1i.e. the one who died first and then the second. [for burial]; and if2So GRA and H. V reads ‘and they do not’. they keep the first overnight3For reasons which follow. they take out the second, because [the Sages] said, ‘Whoever keeps the dead overnight disfigures him’.4Sanh. 46b (Sonc. ed., p. 307) reads ‘transgresses a negative commandment on account of him’, and GRA corrects accordingly. But if [the delay] is to dig a grave for him, or to procure shrouds for him, or to enable his relatives to come from another place, he may be kept overnight and there is no wrong done.5lit. ‘and there is nothing in it’.
When a Sage and a disciple die, they first take out the Sage [for burial]; a disciple and an ‘am ha’areẓ, they first take out the disciple. If both were Sages or disciples or an ’am ha’areẓ they take out the one who dies first. If a man and a woman [died], they first take out the woman because a woman is apt to become disfigured more quickly.6Cf. Rashi on the Mishnah M.Ḳ. 27a.

The differences between man and woman7In respect of funeral rites. are: [the bier of] a man is set down in the broadway8lit. ‘an open space’ in the city where the bier was set down for the delivery of the memorial address. There, too, the ‘benediction of the mourners’ was recited on the return from the cemetery (cf. Keth. 8b, Sonc. ed., p. 37). According to Krauss, Synagogale Altertümer, p. 297, it was the open space in front of the Synagogue, but this definition is disputed; cf. J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, p. 88. but not that of a woman;9‘For the sake of propriety’, M.Ḳ. 27a (Sonc. ed., p. 177). for a man they go up with the ḥeber ‘ir10This term may signify a Rabbi who took a leading part in town affairs, or ‘a group’ denoting either a town council similar to the Roman Collegia or an official communal religious or charitable organization (Meg. 27b, Sonc. ed., p. 164, n. 1). The assembly was usually headed by the Rabbi, and it was considered undignified for him to do so for a woman. but not for a woman; for a male [mourner] the mourners’ meal11Cf. above II, 9, p. 332, n. 18. is provided but not for a female [mourner].12Out of propriety and in order to avoid suspicion of any irregular conduct. R. Judah said: If she has young children, a meal is provided [for her] together with them.

If they have taken out the first [body] and buried him, they do not stand in the row for him, nor do they recite for him the benediction of mourners until they have taken out the second and buried him. When they have taken out the second and buried him, people come and stand in the row and comfort [the mourners], and they thereby exempt the community [from their duty in this matter]. We do not offer consolation to two mourners13Unless they are both related to the dead person. at the same time unless they are of equal status.

We do not take out two dead on one bier unless they are of equal status and [merit] equal praise. It is related of a certain man in Usha14In Galilee. that the house collapsed on his two sons and daughter. People went and inquired of R. Judah [49a] who said, ‘Take out the three of them at the same time’.15On one bier. They placed the bridegrooms16i.e. the sons who but for the accident would later be bridegrooms. at one end [of the bier] and the bride17i.e. the dead daughter. at the other and they lamented, ‘Alas, alas, bridegrooms! Alas, alas, bride!’

We do not deliver two memorial addresses [at the same time] in one city unless there are sufficient to attend each. We do not bewail two brides [at the same time] in one city unless there are sufficient to attend each. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: Even then it is forbidden because of ill-feeling.18People should not fall out in their choice of which to attend.

When a dead person and a bride are being honoured and [the two processions] approach one another, we cause the funeral procession to make way for the bridal procession,19Cf. Keth. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 94). because the honour of the living takes precedence over the honour of the dead. In the case of a royal procession and a bridal procession, the latter makes way20ibid. out of respect for the king. King Agrippa made way for a bride and the Sages praised him. They asked him, ‘What was your reason for doing this?’ He replied, ‘I wear a crown every day but she wears a crown for one hour only’.

We do not21[A less strict ruling is given in ARN IV, 1ff, above pp. 35ff. The probability is that the negative אין is to be deleted. Cf. Büchler, Types of Jewish-Palestinian Piety, p. 86, n. 2.] interrupt the study of the Torah for the sake of a funeral or bridal procession. Abba Saul said: [Good] deeds22i.e. honouring the dead or the bride. take precedence of the study of the Torah. R. Judah acted as follows: Whenever he saw a dead person or a bride being honoured, he used to look at his disciples and exclaim, ‘Deeds before study’.

23Cf. M.Ḳ. 20b (Sonc. ed., p. 131). A woman who is bereaved of her father-in-law or any of her husband’s relatives may not paint her eyelids with kohl or adorn herself, but conducts herself as [her husband] does.24i.e. she observes mourning with him. Likewise if [her husband] is bereaved of his father-in-law or any of his wife’s relatives, he cannot compel her to adorn herself but conducts himself as she does.

25Cf. M.Ḳ. 27a (Sonc. ed., p. 177). Sweeping the floors, washing dishes and making beds do not constitute work for a mourner.26They are permissible.
27The text is in disorder and is corrected according to j.M.Ḳ. III, 5, 83a. A dargesh28An elaborate couch, described in M.Ḳ. 27a (Sonc. ed., pp. 174f). is tilted up29To make it uncomfortable for sleeping or sitting on it. and not overturned. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: He loosens its step30Jastrow defines the word as the ‘step placed before a bed’. The reading in M.Ḳ. is “[In the case of] a dargesh [it is enough if] he unfastens the inner bolster-frame and lets it down’. and leaves it as it is.

Should five brothers eat at their father’s table and he dies, if each of them [usually] goes to his own home to sleep, he overturns [the bed] in his house; but if not, he overturns it only in the house which is used [for sleeping].

If a man possesses five houses, should he be making use of all of them he overturns [the bed] in all of them; if not, he does not overturn it in all of them but only in the house which is used [for sleeping].
If one resides with his friend as a guest, should he be very intimate with him he overturns [the bed there], and if not he does not overturn it.
If one is on a journey and news reaches him that he suffered a bereavement, should he be able to overturn [the bed] with the consent of others he overturns it, and if not he does not overturn it.

One overturns his bed [which is laid] on two benches or on four stones even if there be five mattresses on it, and even though it be [only] four handbreadths31H reads ‘cubits’. above the ground, so long as its legs are tilted upwards.
So long as his dead is lying before him, a mourner may not sleep on a bed [in an erect position] or on an overturned bed.

32Cf. M.Ḳ. 27a (Sonc. ed., p. 175). One who sleeps on a bench or on a bench for water-jugs33Emend to ’uryani, ‘the Roman urnarium, a long oblong bench or kitchen table used for keeping near to hand urns, water vessels and other earthenware utensils and out of the way of being broken’ (M.Ḳ., Sonc. ed., p. 175, n. 8). The words meṭalletha dekarma, ‘a watchman’s hut in the vineyard’ is an incorrect marginal gloss on ’uryani which crept into the text. is subject to the duty of overturning.34Since it is a bed so far as he is concerned. If he declares, ‘I will not overturn the bed but sleep35The translation follows the text of H (cf. the comment in N.Y.). on the bench’, we do not listen to him but say, ‘It is subject to [the law of] overturning’.

The bed has to be overturned six times, five times, four times [or] three times, neither less nor more. How is this? If the death took place close to dusk,36And the burial has taken place so that at nightfall one day of mourning has already gone. [it is done] six times; if close to dusk on the Sabbath-eve five times; if a Festival occurs on the day following the Sabbath four times; in the case of the two days of the New Year [after a Sabbath] three times.37There being no mourning on Sabbaths and Festivals.

38M.Ḳ. 27a (Sonc. ed., p. 173). When does one overturn the bed? From the time the corpse is taken out through the door of the house, according to the view of R. Eliezer. R. Joshua said: From the time the slab closes the tomb. It is related that when Rabban Gamaliel the Elder39Rabban Gamaliel was R. Eliezer’s brother-in-law. died, as soon as he was taken out through the door of his house, [R. Eliezer] said to them,40To his wife Imma Shalom, Rabban Gamaliel’s sister and others in the house; cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit. ‘Overturn your beds’; and when the slab closed the tomb R. Joshua said, Overturn your beds’. They replied, ‘We have already overturned them by order of the Elder’.41viz. R. Eliezer.

1Cf. Zeb. 100b (Sonc. ed., p. 482). The day of hearing2If within thirty days of the death. [the news of the death] is regarded as the day of burial3i.e. his full mourning begins then. for rending [garments], mourning and the observance of the seven [days] and thirty [days]; but as for eating sacred flesh4i.e. of sacrifices if he is a kohen. he is only regarded as one who gathers bones.5A corpse was first buried temporarily in a cave and later transferred to a permanent burial-place in the family tomb. This is termed ‘gathering the bones’; cf. M.Ḳ. I, 5 (Sonc. ed., pp. 40f). By Rabbinical law a man gathering the bones of his father or mother is regarded as a mourner during that day. Both of them may not eat sacred flesh.6On that day only.

R. Eliezer said: [On receiving] ‘near tidings’,7Cf. M.Ḳ. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 127). [that is to say, if news reached him] within thirty days [of the death], one observes [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days]; [if the news reached him] later than this he observes [mourning] for only one day. R. ‘Aḳiba said: On receiving ‘near tidings’ [that is to say, if news reached him] within twelve months [of the death], one observes [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days]. The Sages said: Whether it be ‘near tidings’ or ‘distant tidings’,8After thirty days. he observes [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days]. It is related that when R. Ẓadoḳ’s father died at Ginzaḳ9Gazaka, a city in North Media; according to Rawlinson it is Shiz, near lake Urmia (M.Ḳ., Sonc. ed., p. 128, n. 5). in Media and the news reached him after three years, he observed [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days].

Any [dead person] for whom one rends [the garments] on his death, one also rends for him when his bones are gathered. For [a dead person] for whom one may not baste [the edge of his garments] on his death, one may not baste them when his bones are gathered.

The gathering of bones must be done only during one day; therefore one only gathers them towards dusk.10To reduce the period of mourning. If he gathered them throughout the day and11The words that follow are based on the reading of GRA and H. it became dark, it is permissible [to continue] on the following day. We do not stand in the row for them, nor do we recite over them the benediction of mourners, nor offer consolation to the mourners12By paying a eulogy to the dead. [in public], but we may do so in private. We do not hold an assembly for them in the broadway,13Cf. XI, 2, p. 384, n. 10. but we do bring the mourners’ meal into the mourner’s home.14But not in public as is done after a funeral. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: During the day he lies15The translation follows the emended text of GRA and H. on an overturned bed and at dusk he straightens it.

The following was the practice of the Brotherhoods16Associations organized for the purpose, inter alia, of attending to the dead and mourners. Cf. Krauss, Talmudische Archäologie, II, p. 63 and p. 480, n. 459. in Jerusalem: Some went to the house of mourning, others to the house of feasting,17A marriage feast. some went to a circumcision18lit. ‘the week of the son’, a disguised term for the circumcision ceremony which was adopted during the Hadrianic persecution when the rite was prohibited; cf. B.B., Sonc. ed., p. 246, n. 8. and others to gather bones. [In the choice between going] to the house of mourning and the house of feasting, the house of feasting takes precedence; to a circumcision and to gather bones, the circumcision takes precedence. The pious men of olden days, however, gave precedence to the house of mourning over the house of feasting, for it is stated, It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting; for that is the end of all men, and the living will lay it to his heart.19Eccl. 7, 2. Whoever follows the bier should say, ‘I, too, will follow this one [to the grave]’.
We do not break the bones nor sever the sinews [of a corpse] unless the bones were already broken of their own accord and the sinews severed of their own accord.

A man may gather all bones except those of his father and mother,20But others gather them for him. in the view of R. Joḥanan b. Nuri. R. ‘Aḳiba said: Bones may not be gathered until the flesh dissolves; once the flesh is dissolved the appearance [of the person] is no longer recognizable.21Consequently there is no disrespect to a dead parent if the son gathers the bones.

One may gather the bones of two dead persons at the same time; he then places one collection at one end of the sheet [49b] and the other at the other side of it, in the view of R. ‘Aḳiba. R. Joḥanan b. Nuri said: [If this is done] the sheet may in the end decay and the bones be mixed together; so we gather them and place them [separately] in cedar22According to the text emended by GRA and H. [boxes].

We sprinkle wine and oil upon [the bodies], in the view of R. ‘Aḳiba; R. Simeon b. Nanos said: Oil but not wine because wine causes deterioration;23It is not permitted to hasten their disintegration. and the Sages said: Neither oil nor wine because they breed wood-worms,24So GRA. V is in disorder. but we place dry clods of earth upon them. R. Eliezer b. Ẓadoḳ said: When my father was dying he gave me this instruction, ‘On my death bury me first in a valley, and later gather my bones and place them in a cedar25As emended by GRA. coffin, but do not gather them with your hands’. And I did so for him. R. Joḥanan entered [the cave] and spread a sheet over [the bones]; then I entered, rent [my garments] and spread dry clods of earth [over the bones].26GRA reads ‘and spread a linen sheet over them’. As [my father] did for his father so I did for him.

A man bandages27Correcting מברך to מכרך. and binds [the limb] of a man but not of a woman; a woman bandages and binds both a man and a woman. A man attends to a man suffering from disease of the bowels but not to a woman;28From modesty. a woman attends both to a man29A woman is assumed to be less liable to prurient thoughts. and a woman suffering from disease of the bowels.
Abba Saul b. Bothnith30So H for the unintelligible reading of V. used to say to his sons, ‘Bury me at the feet of my father and remove the thread of blue from [the ẓiẓith of] my cloak’.

31Cf. Pes. 51a (Sonc. ed., pp. 248f) where the text adds ‘brother-in-law’. One may enter a [public] bath with all except32For reasons of modesty. his father, father-in-law, stepfather and his teacher who taught him wisdom. R. Judah said: If his father is old or ill, he may enter and bathe him because that is a way of honouring him.33By attending to his needs.

We do not take out [the dead on] a bier unless his head and the greater part of his body are there. R. Judah said: The spinal column and the skull constitute the greater part. It is related of the son of R. Ḥanina b. Teradion that he took to evil ways and robbers seized and killed him. After three days his swollen body was found; they placed him in a coffin,34According to an emended reading. set him on a bier, took him into the city and paid him a eulogy35For the parallel to this story, cf. Midrash Lamentations 3, 6 (Sonc. ed., p. 195). out of respect for his father and mother. His father quoted over him the verse, And thou moan, when thine end cometh, when thy flesh and thy body are consumed, and say, ‘How have I hated instruction, and my heart despised reproof; neither have I hearkened to the voice of my teachers, nor inclined mine ear to them that instructed me! I was well nigh in all evil in the midst of the congregation and assembly.’36Prov. 5, 11-14. When he had finished he went back to the beginning of the verse. His mother quoted over him the verse, A foolish son is the vexation to his father, and bitterness to her that bore him.37ibid. XVII, 25. His sister quoted over him the verse, Bread of falsehood is sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.38ibid. XX, 17.

One who gathers or guards bones is exempt from reading the Shema‘, the Tefillah, from tefillin and all the commandments prescribed by the Torah. Should he desire to impose a strict view upon himself, he may not do so because of the honour of the bones.1His obedience of laws, from which he is exempt, would result in delay in the burial of the bones. R. Joḥanan b. Nuri said: He should withdraw a distance of four cubits and read [the prayers]. R. Simeon b. ‘Azzai said: If he was travelling on a ship with the bones, he should remove them to another part [of the vessel] and read.2The text is in disorder and the translation follows the version of GRA. R. Isaac said: If they are the bones of a near relative he is exempt, but if of strangers he is under obligation. R. Simeon said: On the Sabbath he is under obligation,3Because if he does not read the prayers he would appear to be mourning on the Sabbath which is not permitted. but on week-days he is exempt. R. Nathan said:4The text is corrupt and emended by GRA. R. Nathan agrees with the ruling that one who guards bones is exempt from the Shema‘, etc., because his concern about their safety may not allow him to concentrate on his religious devotions; but where he carries them in a bundle the question of their safety does not arise and he should be able to concentrate. If the bundle [containing the bones] is with him, he is not exempt5In his note on the text GRA reads ‘is exempt’, but in his annotation to Y.D. ch. 403 he rules that, in the circumstances here described, the man is obliged to read the prayers, etc. because the obligation of guarding [the bones] rests upon him but not the obligation of guarding the bundle.

One who is removing bones or sacred books from one place to another may not place them on a wagon or a ship or an animal and6So GRA and H. V has ‘and not sit’. sit on them; but if it is for their benefit7i.e. for the protection of the bones. or to escape paying ransom to robbers it is permissible.8V inserts here a sentence in brackets which is irrelevant to the subject and is omitted by GRA and H.

If one passes through graves he should not wear the tefillin or carry sacred books in his hand, because it is disrespectful [to the dead].9In Ber. 18a (Sonc. ed., p. 108) he is said to transgress the teaching, Whoso mocketh the poor blasphemeth his Maker (Prov. 17, 5), because the dead are ‘poor’ in that they cannot acquire merit by the study and performance of the Torah.

If one is constructing a burial chamber10Vaults were made in the graves for receiving the dead; cf. Ber. 14b (Sonc. ed., p. 85). [in a cemetery] and the time for reading the Shema‘ arrives, he should not read the Shema‘ or the Tefillah but withdraw to a clean place and read; after that he re-enters [the chamber].

If one finds a dead body in a grave he may not move it from its place,11The dead acquire possession of the spot wherein they are buried. Cf. Sanh. 47b (Sonc. ed., p. 316). unless he knows that the place was lent to it.12Cf. above X, 8. The word ‘lent’ is according to the text of GRA and H.

If one finds bones in a grave he should place them in mounds,13Reading מהמורות defined as ‘mounds used as burying places of executed criminals’ (Jastrow). GRA reads: ‘One who finds bones in mounds should place them in a grave’. in the view of R. ‘Aḳiba; but the Sages said: He should not move them from their place. If he found them in a burial chamber or in a cedar-wood coffin,14So Jastrow. GRA has ‘or in a ravine’. he should not move them from their place.

We may not transfer a dead body or bones from one place of honour to another, or from a place of shame to a place of honour,15The translation follows GRA who alters the text in agreement with j.M.Ḳ. II, 4, 81b. and needless to say from a place of honour to a place of shame; but within [the dead person’s] property it is permissible [to transfer] even from a place of honour to a place of shame, because it is to his honour.16To be buried within his own property.

We do not bury two dead bodies in close proximity to each other, or a dead body in close proximity to bones, or bones in close proximity to a dead body. R. Judah said: Whoever sleeps with him in his lifetime17i.e. young children. is buried with him in his death.18i.e. in close proximity to him.

One may derive benefit from a grave which has been cleared,19Since it is no longer considered the possession of the dead. but he may not turn it into a magazine for straw, a stable, a store for wood or a depot. If one clears a burial chamber he may not make use of it [for any other purpose]. If one prepares a grave for a living person20In preparation for his death. he may sell it; but if he prepared it for the dead he may not sell it. Stones which were hewn21To be used for a sepulchre. for one still living may be sold, but if for the dead they may not be sold. If one clears a coffin he may not make use of it; but if it was made of stone or earthenware it must be broken up, and if of wood it must be burnt. If one finds boards in a cemetery22So emended by GRA. V reads ‘if one carries out boards to a cemetery’. he may not move them from their place.

A watercourse should not be diverted through cemeteries,1Out of respect for the dead; cf. Meg. 29a (Sonc. ed., p. 177). a path should not be cut through them, cattle should not be grazed on them, one should not take a walk there2It should not be used as a short cut. for pleasure, and one should not gather wood or grass from there. If he gathered them he may not make use of them, and if he gathered them for the benefit [of the cemetery]3To clear the ground for more graves. The words in brackets are inserted by GRA and H. he burns them on the spot.
Inherited lands may be conveyed from one [party] to another or alienated from one family to another, but a grave cannot be so conveyed or alienated.4Cf. below, §11.

A new cemetery5In which only a few have been buried. may be measured6To find out how much land had already been used for burials as a guide for further interments. and sold or divided;7Among heirs. an old one may not be measured, sold or divided. A new cemetery may sometimes be regarded as old and an old one as new. An old cemetery in which ten bodies have been buried without the consent of the owners is regarded as new; it may be measured, sold or divided. A new cemetery in which one premature child8Under thirty days old; how much more an adult! lies buried with the consent of the owners is regarded as old; it may not be measured, sold or divided.9‘Or divided’ is added by GRA and H.

No right of legal ownership can be claimed in respect of a cemetery of exiles;10Who in time of pestilence or war move from place to place. in time of pestilence or war no right of legal ownership can be claimed in respect of cemeteries.11This clause is explanatory of the preceding. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Premature children do not acquire possession of their grave.12If buried without the consent of the owners. One who has buried without the consent [of the owner of the land] possesses no right of legal ownership.

A woman who inherited a grave-space is buried therein as also her issue, in the view of R. Meir; R. Judah said: She [is buried there] but not13So GRA and H. V reads ‘and all’ incorrectly. her issue. R. Judah admits that any offspring whom she saw in her lifetime are buried with her [if they die] after her death.14But not a posthumous child. V has ‘on her death’ and the reading of H is adopted.

If her father says, ‘Let her be buried by my side’ and her husband says, ‘Let her be buried [50a] by my side’, she is buried by the side of her father; but if she had children, she is buried by her husband’s side, and if she says, ‘Bury me by the side of my children’, she is buried by their side.

If her father says, ‘She is not to be buried by my side’ and her husband says, ‘She is not to be buried by my side’, she is buried by the side of her husband because her husband has the obligation to support her, redeem her [from captivity],15Cf. Keth. 46b (Sonc. ed., p. 266). bury her and provide all that is necessary16So GRA. for her funeral, [for example,] a bier, pipers17To play at the funeral; cf. B.M. VI, 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 437, n. 3). and wailing women.18Cf. M.Ḳ. III, 9 (Sonc. ed., p. 185). They are mentioned in Jer. 9, 16. Where it is customary to have a memorial address, he has a memorial address delivered over his wife. If her husband does not attend to her [burial, her father] attends to it and the expenses are recovered from [the husband] by force.

19The text is in disorder. The translation follows the emendation of GRA on the basis of Sanh. 47b (Sonc. ed., p. 316). Higger (Introduction, pp. 49f) points out that the text is not in agreement with the parallel passage in Tosiftha Ohol. XVI, 9 or with the Babylonian Talmud loc. cit. or with the Jerusalem Talmud, Nazir IX, 3, 57d. He suggests that the compiler of Semaḥoth must have had before him various passages dealing with the uncleanness of the grave and the prohibition of using graves and he mixed them up. The introductory phrase ‘consequently you may say’ points to the fact that there must have been a discussion on the subject and the statement in the text sums up the conclusion arrived at. Consequently you say that there are three kinds of graves: a grave which has been found may be cleared,20i.e. the bones are transferred to another place. A person had been buried there without the knowledge and consent of the owner. and if cleared its site is [ritually] clean and it is permitted to make use of it. A known grave may not be cleared,21As a precautionary measure against persons contracting defilement. and if cleared its site is [ritually] unclean and it is forbidden to make use of it. A grave which injures the public22Reading המזיק, i.e. a grave which lies in a public thoroughfare and so communicates uncleanness to people who are overshadowed by something which also overshadows it. may not be cleared, and if cleared its site is [ritually] clean but it is forbidden to make use of it.

As regards a cemetery which is enclosed by a city on three sides or on two opposite sides, if it is more than fifty cubits distant from one side [of the city] and more than fifty cubits distant from the other side, it is not23The negative is inserted by GRA and H. cleared and if less it may be cleared.

24The text is reconstructed in agreement with Tosiftha B.B. I, 11. All graves may be cleared except that of a king or a prophet. R. ‘Aḳiba said: The grave of a king or prophet may also be cleared. R. ‘Aḳiba was asked, ‘Were not the graves of the house of David and of Huldah the prophetess25Cf. 2 Kings 22, 14. [situated] in Jerusalem and no man ever touched them?’ He replied, ‘Can you adduce a proof from [Jerusalem]? There was an underground passage there and the uncleanness was conveyed to the brook of Kidron’.26East of Jerusalem.

If one sells to another the path [leading] to his grave, this is no sale.27Because the sale is a slight on his family; cf. B.B. 100b (Sonc. ed., p. 420). If one sells to another his place of mourning,28When, on the return from the cemetery, the cortège halts and the mourners receive condolence; cf. B.B. Sonc. ed., p. 416, n. 8. it is no sale. If one sells29V reads ‘buys’ which is corrected by GRA. to another his halting place,30Where, on returning from the funeral, ceremonial halts were made to offer consolation to the mourners. the elders of the ’Ab Beth Din estimate it as an area of four ḳab.31An area sufficient for sowing four ḳab of seed. A private path [has a width] of four cubits, a public road [a width] of sixteen cubits, the king’s highway has no limits. The path of a funeral cortège has no limits.32The followers may even tread upon cornfields if there is no room for them on the public highway. and the path of [a place of] mourning has no limits.

33Cf. M.Ḳ. 21b (Sonc. ed., p. 136). One who sees a mourner within the thirty days speaks to him words of consolation but does not inquire after his welfare; after thirty days he inquires after his welfare but does not speak to him words of consolation; within the twelve months he inquires after his welfare and then speaks words of consolation to him; after twelve months he speaks to him words of consolation and then inquires after his welfare.
R. Meir said: One who sees a mourner within the thirty days speaks to him words of consolation and then inquires after his welfare; after thirty days but within twelve months he inquires after his welfare and then speaks to him words of consolation; after twelve months he makes no reference at all [to the bereavement]. For R. Meir illustrated the matter by a parable. To what may it be compared? To one who has a wound and was cured of it, and a physician came and said to him, ‘Pay me a fee and I will lance your wound and cure you’. Likewise, whoever reminds a mourner after twelve months [of his bereavement] is accounted as if he had stirred up his wound again. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: To one whose wife died and he remarried within twelve months we speak words of consolation in the street but not in his home.34Not to embarrass his second wife.

All bring to the house of a mourner loaves of white bread, meat and fish, and where an assembly in the broadway35Cf. XII, 4, n. 13. is held also vegetables, peas and fish. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Where it is customary also cooked dishes.36Cf. B.B. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 84). When Abraham died, Jacob made a broth of lentils to comfort his father Isaac.

37Cf. Keth. 8b (Sonc. ed., p. 42), j.Ber. III, 6a. The text here is similar to that of the Jerusalem Talmud. Ten cups of wine are drunk in the house of a mourner: two before the meal, five during the meal and three after the meal, namely one for the benediction of mourners,38The Jerusalem Talmud reads ‘for the Grace after meals’. one for the consolation of the mourners and one [in honour of] charity.39i.e. in honour of those who came to comfort the mourners and performed a pious act. Three more [cups of wine] were added later, namely, one for the Chief of the Synagogue,40An official who administered the external affairs of the Synagogue (cf. Yoma VII, 1, Sonc. ed., p. 322, n. 2). one for the Synagogue attendant41An official who seems to have been next in rank to the Chief of the Synagogue. and one for Rabban Gamaliel.42Who introduced a simple style for funerals to lessen the expense and relieve poor mourners; cf. M.Ḳ. 27b (Sonc. ed., p. 178), Keth. 8b (Sonc. ed., p. 43). When, however, the Beth Din found that people became intoxicated they restored the status quo.43i.e. that ten cups only should be drunk.

He who recites the Grace after meals in the house of a mourner does not say the fourth benediction,44Cf. P.B., p. 283. In Ber. 46b (Sonc. ed., p. 281) the decision is that the benediction is not omitted. in the view of R. Jose the Galilean; R. ‘Aḳiba said: [He recites] ‘Who art kind and dealest kindly’; the Sages said: [The benediction to be recited is, ‘Blessed art Thou] Who art the true Judge, Who rulest over Thy works, Judge of all generations in righteousness, Whose people and servants we all are; and for all this it is our duty to thank and bless Him’.

45Cf. Ber. 54a (Sonc. ed., p. 327). He who sees a place where miracles were wrought for Israel says, ‘Blessed be He Who wrought miracles for our fathers in this place. O give thanks unto the Lord, for He is good’.46Ps. 107, 1.
